did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.physdesc: Manuscripts, printed material, publications, research material, photographs, microfilm
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Research materials on André-Marie Ampère compiled by L. Pearce Williams.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: History of science professor, Cornell University.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Research materials on André-Marie Ampère, including manuscripts and letters by Ampère, and manuscripts by contemporaries such as Etienne Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire, Jan Hendrik van Swinden, Justus Liebig, Charles Bonnet, Jean Senebier, and Maine de Biran. pThis collection consists of William's extensive notes in preparation for a book on Ampère. Includes photocopies of many items from other libraries; they remain in the collection perhaps to show items that Williams found important. Annotations by Williams are prevalent throughout. Order is not entirely clear, but folders may contain Williams's coding for organization. Williams had portions of his writing on Ampère published, but the monograph for which this work was prepared was not finished. Collection also includes microfilm of works by Ampère and his contemporaries.

descgrp.head: INFORMATION FOR USERS

prefercite.head: Cite As:
prefercite.p: Williams Ampère collection, #4730. Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library.

descgrp.head: Restrictions on Use:
descgrp.p: Photocopies or other reproductions may not be quoted or reproduced without the permission of the repository holding the originals.

relatedmaterial.head: RELATED MATERIALS
relatedmaterial.p: Related collection: L. Pearce Williams papers, #14-17-795.

did.unittitle: Letters from Justus Liebig, Charles Friedel, Lalande, and Ernst Wilhelm von Brucke; genealogy of Liebig

Microfilm of Karl Hullmann, Das Grundgesetz der Materie (1863); Friedrich Wilhelm Joseph von Schelling, Zeitschrift fur spekulative Physik (1800-1801); works by Francois-Vincent Raspail and Emile Saigey; and other unidentified microfilms, probably including Ampère material
